newsitem.title: ITALY: SOCCER-ITALIAN CHAMPIONS SINCE WORLD WAR TWO.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-ITALIAN CHAMPIONS SINCE WORLD WAR TWO.

text.p: Juventus won the Italian league title for the 24th time on Friday when they drew 1-1 with Atalanta.
Title winners and runners-up since the Italian serie A re-started in 1945 after World War Two:
Since the League began in 1898 the following clubs have won the title:
7 - Torino (+1 title in 1927 revoked by Italian federation. The title was not awarded), Pro Vercelli and Bologna
1 - Casale, Novese, Cagliari, Lazio, Verona and Sampdoria.
NOTES - The soccer league was suspended due to war between 1916 and 1919 and in 1944, when a wartime championship of upper Italy was won by the La Spezia fire brigade.
The first Italian champions were Genoa, who won the title for the first three seasons and six times in seven years.
In 1906 Juventus pulled out of a playoff final with Milan in protest at the game being held in Milan.
In 1908, only four teams took part with Milan, Torino and Genoa absent because of a federation ruling restricting the championship to Italian players only.

In 1910 Inter won a playoff 10-3 after finishing level on points with Pro-Vercelli, who fielded a team of 11-year olds in protest because the fixture coincided with their best players being away in military tournaments.
In 1921-22 Pro-Vercelli and Novese shared the title.
In 1948-49, Torino were declared champions after most of the team died in an air crash with four matches remaining.
